document.title: Anja user's guide
document.author: Torbjörn Rathsman

abstract.p: Anja is a sample player designed for live sound effect playback. Anja makes it possible to assign sound effects to the keys of the computer keyboard. Anja also featrues a channel mixer with 16 channels, making it possible to fade a group of sound effects together. The backend of Anja is JACK, the low-latency audio server. The session file format of Anja is in a formalized text format, optimized for human readability.

document.p: Anja is a sample player designed for live sound effect playback. Anja makes it possible to assign sound effects to the keys typing keys of the computer keyboard. To make it easier to find sound effects, each sound effect can have a description and a color, that shows up on Anja's virtual computer keyboard.

Anja also features a channel mixer with 16 channels. All sound effects are routed through one of these channels. The channel mixer makes it possible to fade a group of sound effects together. As with sound effects, each channel has a color and a description. In addition to color, description and channel gain, each channel also has an adjustable fade time, that is used to automatically fade the channel.
The backend of Anja is JACK, the low-latency audio serverjack. This makes it possible to connect Anja to other JACK clients enabling the creation of more complex signal flows.

The session file format of Anja is in a formalized text format, optimized for human readability. The syntax of the session files has taken inspiration from formats such as Markdownmarkdown and is very similar to the syntax used in the "Doom template file"doomwiki. Therefore, session files can be easiliy edited by hand in a text editor, to the price of somewhat larger session files.

To run Anja, a working installation of JACKjack is required. Moreover, Anja requires libsndfile and GTK+ version 3. Anja runs smoothly on an Intel® Pentium® M, and thus, it is only moderately CPU demanding. However, since Anja completely loads all sound files referenced from a session file, it may consume some RAM. At 48, the RAM usage is 11 of sound. The minimum screen resolution for running Anja in fullscreen mode is 923 × 599. In windowed mode, the required screen resolution depends on the windowing system, but it is approximately 930 × 630.

There are other sample players that also may be used with JACK. One such program is Hydrogenhydrogen. Compared to Hydrogen, Anja lacks a sequencer. However, in Hydrogen, waveforms need to be assigned in a particular order, and Hydrogen does not feature an on-screen keyboard. Other features in Anja is event-triggerd auto-fade, and also a kill-all-softly feature.
Before Anja can be used, the program needs to be installed. This chapter goes through the installation procedure.

On GNU/Linux, the recommended way of installing Anja is to install it from the software repository. If there is no package available, download the source packageanjasrc, and compile it as according to the instructions in compile.

Before Anja can be compiled, certain programs, and development packages are needed. These are listed in depstab, together with their purpose. Obeserve that some of the packages may need a corresponding development package. On Ubuntu, these packages usually have the suffix dev. Anja has been written using the wand build tool. Therefore, this program has to be available when Anja is compiled. The makefile distributed with Anja, tries to detect wand before the compilation starts. If the makefile fails to detect wand, a package containing wand is downloaded from the author's GitHub repository by using wget.

Starting Anja without any command line arguments brings up a window that looks like the one presented in anjastart. The workspace consits of three main parts annotated in anjaworkspace. To the left, there the Action panel a panel with different buttons that affect Anja's current state. To the right of that, the Keyboard view is located, and below that, there is a Settings panel, controling which waveforms are loaded as well as the playback of loaded waveforms. Above the Keyboard view, there is an area for text messages indicating the state of the audio engine.

figure.caption: The Anja window, as shown after launching Anja without any command line arguments

The different parts of the Anja workspace. (1) is the Action panel, used to control Anja's state, (2) is the Keyboard view, which selects waveform slots and channels, and (3) is the Settings panel, which controls which loads waveforms and controls the playback of loaded waveforms.

document.p: To load a waveform, choose a slot by clicking on the corresponding key in the Keyboard view. It is possible to choose any key except one of the function keys, but it is recommended to avoid the keys Alt and ❖. After choosing a slot click Browse... to the right of Source field now visible in the Settings panel. This brings up a file selection dialog. It is also possible to type a filename directly in the text input field to the left of Browse....
document.infobox: In case a multi-channel audio file is loaded, only the data for the first (usually the "left" channel) will be loaded. This is because Anja uses mono waveforms. For information about playing multi-channel audio, see multichannel.
document.p: Before any sound can be heard from Anja, the audio engine has to be running. The audio engine is started by clicking the button Start engine in the Action panel. Now, when the engine is running, there should be a new JACK client with a name that derived from the name of the current Anja session. For example, after starting the engine on the default session, there should be a JACK client called New session.anja. To list all JACK clients and ports open a teminal and type
If you did not load any old session, or have not modified the default session, you will see something like
document.code: system:capture_1 system:capture_2 system:playback_1 system:playback_2 New session.anja:Master out New session.anja:Audio capture New session.anja:MIDI in New session.anja:MIDI out
document.p: The interesting port in this case is New session.anja:Master out. Connecting this port to system:playback_1 and system:playback_2 will enable sound output from Anja to the left and right speaker (or what ever is connected to the corresponding audio output ports of the computer). JACK ports can be connected by using the command jack_connectmanjack. The command to connect these ports would be
document.code: jack_connect 'New session.anja:Master out' 'system:playback_1' jack_connect 'New session.anja:Master out' 'system:playback_2'
document.p: The status message shown when the audio engine is running suggests using a JACK patchbay tool such as Catiacatia shown in catia. In Catia ports can be connected using "Drag and drop".

When the audio engine is started, and the output port is connected, a loaded waveform can be played by hitting the corresponding key on the computer keyboard. Depending on playback options (see pboptions), playback is stopped by releasing the key, or when the playback position reaches the end cursor (see waveformtrim).
document.infobox: Triggering playback through the computer keyboard is only possible when the Keyboard view has keyboard focus. This is indicated by a green rectangle.

figure.caption: Catia with an Anja session started

document.p: Similar to waveform playback (see play), waveform capture requires that the audio engine is started. In order to capture a waveform, make sure that Audio capture is connected to a signal source. Then press Ins and the typeing area key K that should be used for playing the captured waveform. If the Ins is released before the typing area key, the captured waveform will be playback of the recorded waveform is triggered. If K is released first, the capture process is stoppped.
document.infobox: Triggering audio capture through the computer keyboard is only possible when the Keyboard view has keyboard focus. This is indicated by a green rectangle.
It is not possible to record waveforms to a slot that has been marked as read-only. See waveformprop form more information.

Capturing waveforms stores the waveform in virtual memory. This means that it is not possible to record longer waveforms. Also, trying to do so may crash Anja. See requirements for information about memory requirements.
document.p: The playaback behaviour and other properties can be controlled through the Waveform data tab in the Settings panel (Area (3) in anjaworkspace). An enlarged view of the Waveform data panel is shown in waveformdata. This view is activated by clicking on the corresponding key on the keyboard view (Area (2) in anjaworkspace).

figure.caption: An enlarged view of the Settings panel showing waveform data. This panel contains various settings controlling playback of the selected slot.

document.p: The source file is chosen throught the Source field. By clicking Browse, a file selection dialog appears. When a different wave file is selected Anja replaces the waveform associated with current slot, with the waveform loaded from the chosen file. For information about supported file formats, see fileformats.
document.infobox: It is not possible to load another waveform when the current slot is in use by the engine.
Changing the source file from disk does not affect Anja, since Anja loads the file into memory.
Avoid loading large files. Doing so, may exhaust system memory. See requirements for information about memory requirements.
document.p: It is possible to assign an arbitrary description to the waveform slot through the Description field. The description does not affect the waveform playback, but makes it easier to find the waveform in the Keyboard view.

It may happen that the description is long. Therefore it is possible to mark a key-phrase by surrounding it with square brackets. Then, only the text within the first pair of square brackets will appear at the virtual key. If there are no square brackets within the description, the first word will be used instead.

Like description (see description), the Color field is only used for visual enhancements. The color is given as red-green-blue-alpha values delimited by ;, where each component is in the range [0, 1]. If the ... is pressed a color selection dialog based on the HSL color system appears. This dialog is described in more detail in colordlg.
document.infobox: The idea behind color coding of waveform slots is that slots that are used in similar context can be encoded with a similar color. The color coding feature can be used to categorize different kinds of waveforms such as Fx and Ambient.
document.p: The Playback channel field assigns a channel to the waveform slot. All sound from this slot will be routed through the selected channel.
document.infobox: Channels can be used to fade multiple sound sources together. The mix of all channels can either be controlled by the internal Channel mixer (see chmixer), or by an external mixer (see sessprop).
document.p: Before the signal reaches the strip for the selected playback channel (see pbchannel), the signal is amplified by the given playback gain. The gain can be adjusted from -72 to 6.

In addition to deterministic playback gain adjustment, it is possible to add a non-deterministic component to the playback gain. The parameter Playback gain random level sets how much the random component is amplified.
document.infobox: Depending on the state of the Set gain on loop flag (see pboptgainrand), new random numbers are drawn on manual retriggering, or for each iteration when playback loop is active. This can be useful on machinegun effects.
document.p: There are different options for controlling the playback behavior. These are Loop, Sustain, Readonly, and Set gain on loop.
When Loop is enabled, playback will start form the beginning when the playback position reaches the end cursor, if no stopping event has occurred before that happens.
The Sustain flag controls whether or not a key release event should also send a stop event. When the Sustain flag is set, a stop event is not sent, emulating the effect of a pushed sustain pedal.
The Readonly flag controls whether or not it is possible to overwrite a loaded waveform with captured audio (see rec). Enabling Readonly prevents that a loaded waveform is accidentally overwritten.
As mentioned in pbgainrandom, it is possible to only randomize gain on the trig event, but it is also possble set a new gain for each iteration in a loop. When this flag is set, the latter happens.

It may happen that only a portion of a loaded waveform is interesting. With the Trim panel, it is possible to select the part of the waveform that should be played. The graph shows in dBFS, the root mean square power integrated over 1, as a function of time in seconds. On to of the power function, there are three cursors that can be moved by click and drag.

The green cursor marks the playback starting position. The red one marks the stopping position. The positions are moved by moving the corresponding cursor to the desired position. The start and stop position can also be set by typing their positions into the corresponding input fields, Begin and end. The positions are in this case given in seconds.
document.infobox: If the end cursor has been placed to the left of the begin cursor, Anja will play the wavefile backwards.

If a more detailed view of a certain part of the loaded waveform is needed in order to set the start ans stop positions, it is possible to zoom in on the current range by pressing Z. If X is pressed, the view will return to the previous view.
document.p: In addition to manually adjusting the playback range, it is possible to let Anja compute a range automatically. In this case, Anja will use the first and last positions where the signal level exceeds a certain threshold level, start and stop positions. The threshold can be adjusted by moving the yellow (horisontal) cursor to a suitable level. Clicking on one of the Auto buttons will adjust the corresponding position. If the Shift is pressed while the yellow cursor is moved, Anja will adjust both positions accordingly.

The Channel mixer is shown in channelmixerfig. The Channel mixer controls the playback volume for the different playback channels. To the right of all channel strips, there is a master gain control, which controls the playback volume of the mixed channels. In addition to a gain control, each channel strip also contains an input field for selecting a channel color, which works similar to the color input field for waveforms (see wavecolor), and a control for determining the time constant for automatic fade-in/out.

figure.caption: The Channel mixer. Each channel strip has a label, a color, a fade time knob, and a volume slider. To the right of all strips, there is a master gain control, that affects the gain of the mix.

document.infobox: It may be a good idea to match the channel colors in some way to the colors used for the waveform associated with the playback channel. This makes it easier to find the right channel strip in the Channel mixer.

The knob for controlling the time constant for autofade works in polar coordinates. If it is hard to find the right value, try to increase the distance to the knob center when adjusting the corresponding value
document.p: Automatic fade-in/out is triggered by hitting Fk while pressing ↑/↓, where k is the channel number. After fade-out, the channel is muted until it is unmuted or a fade-in occures. Mute and unmuting a channel is done by hitting the corresponding channel key (Fk) while pressing ← or → respectively.
document.infobox: It is only possible to access channel 1 to 12 from the PC keyboard. In order to autofade channel 13-16, an external MIDI controller can be used, see midi.
Using the PC keyboard to trigg fade-in/out is only possible when the Keybord view is active.
document.p: Anja has the option to use individual channel output. This enables the use of external effect processors on the different channels. The option is activated by checking the checkbox Use individual ports for each channel in the Session properties (see sessprops) panel. When individual ports are used for different channels, Anja creates one JACK port for each of the 16 channels in addition to Master out. The signal sent to these channels are taken after the corresponding channel strip, but before the master gain adjustment.

If the split signal needs to be mixed before sent to another JACK client, it is possible to connect all ports to the same input port. In this case, it might be good to use non-mixer to adjust the total output gain.
document.infobox: Toggeling multi-channel output requires the engine to be restarted.

figure.caption: The Session properties panel. From this panel, it is possible to give the session a title and a description, as well as enabling multichannel output (see multichannel).

document.p: Anja uses libsndfile in order to load wave files. Thus the file formats supported by Anja, are the same as the file formats supported by libsndfile.
